review_blob: The rye malt adds a tartness to both the aroma and flavor, nicely balancing the floral and citric hops.  The ordinary appearance does not suggest the depth of malt flavor and long finish.  A nice variation on the APA formula.

Biscuity malts and earthy hops come through clearly in the aroma.  It pours a clear dark amber color with medium body, good head retention, and plenty of hop lace.  The taste favors hops over malt, and the palate retains some sweetness.  A very good example of the Marzen style, but the best (Ayinger) overshadows the good (Spaten).

The product meets the promise here, about halfway between pilsner and Marzen.  Bread and toast aromas are spiced with herbal hops.  The hops appear in the pour, leaving a light hop lace, with a typical light amber color.   Medium body, medium bitterness, soft carbonation, and lingering hops.   The final balance tilts toward pilsner but without the astringency.

Opens with a roasty aroma with licorice and chocolate notes, and pours dark but not heavy.  Taste is very well balanced once it reaches 50 F (10 C).  Medium body, light carbonation, and a rather short finish.  Compared to its archrival Bells Kalamazoo Stout, it seems a bit bland.

12-oz. can center poured into pint glass.  Biscuity and yeasty aroma, dark amber color, and light but firm carbonation all reflect a German lager style.  Moderately sweet flavor with light earthy hops, with less malt than the aroma suggested.  Light body for the 5 percent ABV content, which is quite apparent in the palate, given the soft carbonation and otherwise short finish.  Overall a decent mass produced lager, but it shows no signs of excellence.

A citrus hop aroma invites further exploration, along with pronounced hop lace.  The flavor is very gentle for 70 IBUs, with plenty of resin, pine, and citrus notes and a light malt sweetness with almost no yeast artifacts.  The hop resins create an oily/sticky texture offset by abundant carbonation.  Overall a full-bodied, clean, and well-balanced IPA.

A strong caramel malt aroma with a bit of nuttiness led me to expect a British-style ESB.  The color relects the style but the lack of carbonation was not a good sign.  Caramel malt dominates the flavor, with a light earthy hoppiness and some estery yeast artifacts.  The esters and a bit of alcohol linger in the finish.  While not a bad beer, many of its rivals are much better.

Sweet corn aroma with some grassy hop notes.  Light foamy head quickly dissipates to a pale amber color.  Pale malt and rice offset the corn sweetness.  A rather thin texture and lively carbonation make PBR drinkable, if not memorable.  Overall a well-balanced and cheap macro lager, IMO a better value than the "big 3."

Kellerweis stands toe-to-toe with the best Bavarian weizens.  The aroma fairly reeks of banana and clove, while the very cloudy, lacy pour perfectly matches the style.  The flavor likewise is banana and clove with a light sourness and a light herbal hoppiness.  The texture is markedly creamy and soft, but the finish is rather short.  Nevertheless this is a very refreshing summer beer.

beer_brewer_name: Leinenkugel Brewing Company (Tenth & Blake Beer Co.)
review_blob: Bready malt aroma suggests a German-style lager.  It pours a clear light amber with a minimal white head.  Quite agreeable malt flavor, lightly hopped, and lightly sweet.  This wouldnt displace Sam Adams but is still much better than the standard Bud/Coors/Miller lagers.

Caramel malt underlays the spruce and citrus hop aromas.  Torpedo pours a hazy amber with a rocky head and hop lacing. Light sweetness, slight ale yeast notes, and very bitter.  Full body, resinous texture, soft carbonation, and a long astringent finish with the spruce up front and the citrus in the throat.  Magnum is a hop to reckon with, probably a hybrid of several Pacific Northwest varities, and Sierra Nevada has provided a full caramel malt backdrop

Spicy hops and bready malt blend well in the aroma.  Light amber color, medium body, and mild hop lacing in the glass indicate a real pilsner style.  A citrus tang underlays the spicy noble hop flavor, along with a rather small bready pale malt flavor.  The hops and a bit of residual sourness lingers in the palate.  Urquell still remains the best pilsner palate IMO.  Samuel Adams has made a very good if not great pilsner.

Rich, complex hop aroma, good carbonation, and ample hop lace promise a hop bomb.  The flavor delivers deep, lasting hop presence, balanced between citrus and earthy bitterness, and finishes long with its dry hopping.  The caramel malt does not quite offset the massive hop infusion, but the blend of hops can be admired on its own.

The aroma and pour are decent enough but do not really suggest the level of excellence the flavor and palate display.
The crystal malt rounds out the pale malt, just as the Liberty hops add floral notes to the citric Cascades.  All these ingredients blend and balance very well indeed.

The complex malts and simple hops blend well in the aroma.  It pours a dark, viscous brown with plenty of hop lace.  The malt flavors blend about halfway between brown ale and stout.  The roasted malt takes over the finish, which detracts from the flavor and palate.  A long hop finish and alcohol warmth mitigate the burnt flavors.  With a bit less roasted malt, this would dominate the category.  Overall a very good near miss.

Copper Hook pours with a light, clean pale malt aroma and modest hops.  It pours a clear light amber with little head retention.  The flavor closely resembles the aroma, a clean if nondeScript malt-forward blend.  Lack of carbonation detracts from the palate.  This is probably the best-balanced beer Red Hook currently produces, which no longer says much.

The aroma resembles a Dortmunder more than a Pilsner, but the pour produces plenty of off-white frothy head.  The clear light amber color also suggests a Dortmunder.  Some stale grain flavors detract from the decent but not distinctive flavor, which lacks hop presence.  If compared to Budweiser, Simpler Times wins, but many American craft brewers produce better Pilsner.

A humorous name for a good but not great pilsner.  The pour suggests a light, fizzy texture, but upon swirling in the glass, more body becomes apparent.  The aroma has some "dirty" notes (well said, drink4satan) of straw and cereal grain along with the expected pale malt and hop notes.  The flavor is rather sweet for a pilsner, more sugary than malty, and the Saaz hops do not assert themselves as they do with Urquell.  Some sugar and hops remain in the short finish.  IMO, Victory Prima Pils remains several notches above Oskar Blues latest effort.
beer_name: Oskar Blues Mamas Little Yella Pils

review_blob: UPDATED: MAY 13, 2009

Malts dominate the nose with only a slight hop aroma.  Medium ruby color, slight head, but durable carbonation.  Caramel and chocolate malt flavors balance with some nuttiness.  Some residual sugar and acid in the finish.  This isnt bad, but Rogue and Dogfish still rule this particular style.
beer_name: Tregs Rugged Trail Nut Brown Ale

review_blob: Bread yeast, orange, and honey aromas entice the drinker into a deep pour.  Local 2 pours a very cloudy dark brown color with durable, fine carbonation and a bit of hop lace.  Earthy hops and plenty of orange peel offset honey-sweetened caramel and dark malt.  The finish is citrus and alcohol warmth without cloying sweetness.

La Fin du Monde smells like a strong hefeweizen with spicy notes.  It also pours like one with plenty of short-lived frothiness and cloudiness.  A warming alcohol glow permeates the clove, spice, and apricot flavors.  The palate is deceptively light, probably a result of the triple fermentation.  While lacking the firmness and character of Aventinus (still my reference for strong wheat beers), this is still a well-balanced, enjoyable beer.

Hang Ten is cleanly brewed but much simpler than Aventinus, which it tries to emulate.  Its aroma is sweet and clovey, but no other flavors emerge.  The extra alcohol is readily apparent, but doesnt add to the experience.  I cant seriously recommend Aventinus fans like myself to switch loyalties.
beer_name: Heavy Seas Mutiny Fleet Hang Ten

review_blob: The original Pilsner is still a contender. It begins with Saaz hop, malt, and apple notes in the aroma.  Beautiful pale amber color, crystalline in appearance, with a light but firm head.  The hops hit up front but do not linger, then the pale malt takes over.  Apple-like tartness lingers in the finish.  Warning: this beer lends itself to session drinking if youre not careful!

I just bought my second six-pack of the 2008 version, and I am not disappointed.  Sierra Nevada promised a fresh hop bomb and delivered the expected impact.  Very fresh Cascades slam the nose upon opening the bottle.  It pours a light amber with plenty of head retention and hop lacing.  There is not quite enough malt body to balance the fresh, deep hop flavor, but the finish is clean and the hops linger.

Yeasty, sugary notes dominate the aroma.  It pours a very dark amber, almost brown, and indeed the malt resembles a brown ale.   The flavor is sweet and yeasty with some floral notes.  Weighty texture with some alcohol notes.  Yeast and sugar dominate the palate, not entirely to its benefit.   I am probably signing my sentence to Hell by not writing a rave review of the Trappist efforts, but I am underwhelmed.  Both the Premiere and Cinq Cents are better balanced.

A sweet, malty aroma invites further exploration. The pour reveals light carbonation and a clear dark amber color.  The flavor likewise is malty with brown sugar and an earthy hop throat.  The finish is quite clean with some alcohol burn.  This is not my first choice in barleywine-style ales, but decent.
beer_name: Heavy Seas Mutiny Fleet Below Decks

review_blob: The distinctive malt blend announces itself from the very first whiff.  It pours a clear dark amber with very fine, diffuse carbonation and a slight hop lace.  The caramel malt asserts itself in the flavor, with slight earthy hops and diacetyl yeast notes.  The finish is quite sweet, perhaps too much so.  This is not a session ale, but a decent malt dessert.

The nutmeg really blends well with the wheat aroma without overwhelming it.  Sams Winter Lager pours with just-right carbonation and plenty of lacing and head retention.  The flavor is very clean with subdued wheat and noble hop flavors.  The spice lingers in the finish, detracting somewhat from the palate.  The mouthfeel is just right.  Overall a well-brewed weizenbock which just lacks the complexity and depth of its German counterparts.

Bud Ale pours a medium amber with plenty of head retention and a distinctly diacetyl aroma.  The diacetyl character also dominates the finish.  The malt flavor closely resembles Michelob Amber Bock with its caramel malt, yet departs from it with a more floral hop flavor (the Cascades).  Again like Michelob, the mouthfeel lacks body.  Overall a near miss which could use a less exaggerated yeast character.

The Bud can I poured into a pint glass required a slow pour up the middle to release the excess gas.  Once it dissipated it had almost no lacing or head retention, and was quite pale.  Fermented rice dominates the aroma, but the malt and hop notes eventually came through.  No off-flavors in my sample, but not much malt or hop flavor either.  Those components balanced quite well.  Some high-alcohol yeast artifacts emerged in the palate, suggesting that A-B dilutes a much stronger beer.  Very little aftertaste other than a residual sweetness.  I have to admire A-Bs considerable brewing skills, but of course the recipe hits the lowest common denominator.

After rating an excellent Ommegang, this Flying Dog is a disappointment.  It smells like a German pilsner but with wild yeast.  Likewise it pours like a lager but without much hop lace or head retention.  The pale malt is nice enough, and the French hops add some pleasant floral notes.  Hop astringency and malt sweetness compete in the palate.  Sorry Flying Dog, but this does not distinguish itself.
beer_name: Flying Dog Garde Dog Bire de Garde

review_blob: Three Philosophers is hard to fault on any count.  It smells, pours, and tastes like a good tripel plus a small amount of kriek.  Whats more, the total experience exceeds the sum of its parts.  The Trappist beers are a bit more complex, but this is very well balanced in every aspect.

Amber Bock opens with a light, frothy head which dissipates quickly.  The aroma nicely balances caramel malt and noble hops.  While not very complex, the caramel malt comes through cleanly, with light but firm hops and just a whiff of lager-yeast sulfur.  The mouthfeel has plenty of body and leaves some malt sweetness.  While not my first choice, Anheuser-Busch still makes very good lagers when they dont add rice!

Raven smells bready and grainy and pours a cloudy light amber.  Sweet malt dominates the flavor, chased by light but firm noble hops.  Some sourness detracts from the palate.  Malt and hops balance well in the short finish, but the texture lacks body.  Raven would be good at half the price--then it would be Yuengling.

Citric hops and sweet caramel malts dominate the palate.  It pours a cloudy dark amber with marked hop lace and fine, light carbonation.  Sweet caramel malt and plenty of high-alpha hops dominate the flavor, with some crystal malt in the mix.  Alcohol and dry hops in the throat provide an astringent finish.  Stone Double Bastard remains my favorite example, followed by Dogfish 90 Minute, but Oskar Blues Gordon is quite respectable.
UPDATED: MAR 22, 2009

While not the last word in complexity, Old Chub is still a balanced, vastly enjoyable brew!  The aroma resembles a good chocolate cake right out of the oven.  It pours a dark but clear brown with a reddish cast and ample head retention and lacing.  The flavor celebrates malt without overpowering viscosity or sweetness.  The smokiness lingers in the finish, along with a slight alcohol burn.  Well done.

The aroma and appearance are clean but not distinctive.  However the flavor shows off the brewers considerable skill.  The multiple hops are at once earthy, astringent, and floral.  The pale malts are full-bodied with sweet, peachy undertones, and provide a viscous texture.  A slightly sweet finish with lingering hops on the front of the tongue.

Nice authentic English malt (biscuity) and hop aroma upon opening.  Plenty of carbonation, with a rather dark, cloudy appearance.  Good clean pale malt combines with more earthy hops than the English would use.  The lack of filtering benefits the mouthfeel, palate, and flavor.  A very good ESB with an American accent.

Holy Ale smells, pours, and tastes like a typical session bitter without quite achieving greatness.  Although pasteurized it leaves a lot of dead yeast residue, so drinker beware!  The malt aroma and flavor are quite clean, the residual sugar and yeast do not intrude too much, and the hops are cleanly extracted at about the right level.  Competent but not quite excellent.
beer_name: Black Sheep Monty Pythons Holy Grail (Bottle)

review_blob: Bottle from The Virginia Touch.  Grassy aroma, clear light amber pour with a slight head.  Clean pale malt leads the flavor profile, with light noble hops, some grass, and just a whiff of lager-yeast sulfur.  Quite substantial body from the malt, and a clean finish with moderate residual sweetness.  This is very much a lager, not a pilsner.

On draft at the brewery, Full Nelson smells like the real deal.  Piney hop notes dominate, followed by citrus, a slight floral nose, and light pure pale malt.  It left plenty of hop lace and poured a clear light amber.  The freshness, depth, and complexity of hop flavors stunned my palate, and the clean, un-husky pale malt did not distract.  The hops also dominated the palate.  I found this worth the trip, and would actually drive to central Virginia to have this again.
beer_name: Blue Mountain Full Nelson Pale Ale

review_blob: The chicory asserts itself even above the sharp roasted barley aroma.  It pours a clear dark brown with a slight hop lace and a durable head.  The flavor blends the many ingredients to near perfection.  Chicory, coffee, and licorice add harmony and depth to the roasted malt, which provides a medium body.  The finish is very clean, slightly sweet with some hops in the backthroat.  Id recommend the bottles, but the draft version is even better, featuring even fresher coffee and malt flavors.

The aroma registed a typical dunkel malt profile but not much hops.  It pours a clear dark ruby with light carbonation and some viscosity.  The flavor is mainly a clean, balanced blend of chocolate and caramel malt.  It leaves a mild sweetness and a slight alcohol burn, and the texture is quite full.   I could stand more hoppiness, but I still enjoyed this one.  However at the retail price it does not stand up to its competitors.

beer_brewer_name: Old Dominion Brewing Company (Coastal Brewing Co.)
review_blob: The aroma registers earthy hops and a sourdough yeastiness.  It pours somewhat frothy, but the head is short-lived.  The flavor nicely balances German-derived hops with a doughy breadiness.  The lager yeast is very nice, leaving only slight sulfur notes and that unique sourdough character.  The  Breiss-derived malt huskiness detracts from an otherwise clean palate.  Overall a very decent Dortmunder.

The Blond opens with a yeasty aroma followed by wheat, clove, and Noble hop notes.  It pours more like an unfiltered lager than a weizen with subdued carbonation.  The flavor resembles a weizen with marked yeast notes and some residual sweetness.  In my opinion the yeastiness detracts from the palate, although the mouthfeel is very malty.  I prefer Orval in this style, with Chimay Blanche a close second.

The malt, yeast, and hop aromas all resembled the style.  The pour lacks carbonation but maintains a nice hop lace.  The flavor is clean but lacks the malt roundness the better German examples provide.  Its dry, sulfury finish resembles a Dortmunder.  Overall it exemplifies the style fairly well but lacks greatness.

The dark malt aroma and thick, cloudy pour do not really indicate the excellence of Storm Kings balance.  I never expected an imperial stout to be this drinkable!  The flavor lacks the last bit of malt depth (try Brooklyn Chocolate Stout) but features a subtle PNW hop profile and vanilla notes.  The roast malt and alcohol linger in the finish.
UPDATED: OCT 28, 2007
